comments.body:
Shouldn't this line be word-wrapped like the others ?

Your editor probably has a feature, in vim it's `gqq`
it does, but i purposefully avoid the 80 col nonsense since most monitors exceeded that limit in 1992.

Unfortunately, you need to word wrap this and your other entries here as well.  The reason is that we'the wrong markup for these areas.  We're using `::` which means a code block or preformatted text.  So long lines are not going to wrap in the html display either.

We shold probably be using definition lists for all of these instead of code blocks.  As a short example that would look like:

```
:ansible_ssh_extra_args:
       This setting is always appended to the default ssh command line.
:ansible_ssh_pipelining: Determines whether or not to use SSH pipelining. This can override the ``pipelining`` setting in ``ansible.cfg``.
```

( The definition can start on the same line as the definition term or the next line.  If you have line breaks (I set mine at 160 chars in a compromise between you and sanity ;-) subsequent lines just need to be indented.

I'll leave it up to you whether you want to add line breaks or reformat the lists to be definition lists instead.
i'm fine with change to definition lists, but would make that a subsequent PR and not part of this one

comments.body: I don't think allowed shells matters because we're invoking it as a command, not as a login shell.  So this probably should be if /bin/sh is not available or not present on the machine.

We probably also want to say something about ansible_shell_type needing to agree with this setting.  maybe in the ansible_shell_type documentation (since autodetection means that you might not need to set shell_type when you set executable but you always need to set executable if you set shell_type).

```
-       The shell type of the target system. You should not use this setting unless you have set the 'executable' to a non sh compatible shell.
+       The shell type of the target system. You should not use this setting unless you have set the 'ansible_executable' inventory variable to a non sh compatible shell.
```

And then for here we do need to change the list of allowed shells to something like installed on the system.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +268,272 @@      This sets the shell the ansible controller will use on the target machine, overrides ``executable`` in ``ansible.cfg`` which defaults to '/bin/sh'.
      You should really only change it if is not possible to use '/bin/sh' (i.e. it is not in the list of allowed shells for your users).
